sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'
  import { MDXTag } from '@mdx-js/tag'
  

export default class MDXContent extends React.Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props)
    this.layout = null
  }
  render() {
    const { components, ...props } = this.props

    return <MDXTag
             name="wrapper"
             
             components={components}><MDXTag name="h1" components={components} props={{"id":"mastering-logical-fallacies---michael-withey"}}>{`Mastering Logical Fallacies - Michael Withey`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"ad-hominems"}}>{`Ad Hominems`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ol" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`Abusive - claim someone to be a bigot/racist etc to discredit their argument`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`Circumstantial - claim a circumstance to discredit their argument ie discrediting someone because "they are just saying that to get permission"`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`Guilt by association - discredit an argument due to affiliation`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ol">{`Tu quoque - discrediting an argument becaues the proponent engages in such an act. Ie someone might be a hypocrite for smoking and saying it is bad, but their argument is still valid.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="h2" components={components} props={{"id":"other-fallacies"}}>{`Other fallacies`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="ul" components={components}>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Affirming the consequent: "If I had a deadly disease, I would have a cough. I have a cough, therefore I have a deadly disease."`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Ambiguity: "A is B, A is C, so B is C."`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Anonymous Authority: confirmation by someone who may not be an expert.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to anger: appeals to the anger of the audience`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to authority: does not offer direct evidence for argument P, but an appeal to the testimony of an authority.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to celebrity`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to common belief`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to desperation: demanding an action to be performed to resolve a situation, regardless of whether the proposed action will in fact resolve the situation`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to emotion: appeals to the emotions of the audience`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to faith`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to fear: playing off the audience's fear`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to heaven`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to the moon`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to nature: fallacy based on suggesting things are unnatural and therefore not valid`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to normality`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to pity`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to possibility`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to ridicule`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Appeal to tradition: claiming reasoning through traditional means`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Argument from ignorance: The argument and assumption that something is false due to a lack of evidence that it is true`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Base rate: information regarding probability is ignore when estimating how likely it is to occur in a particular case`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Begging the question: An argument based on the truth of its conclusion. "People are always self-intested. Whenever speaking on welfare, they are for their own good. Hence, we see peope are always self-interested.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Biased sample`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Blind authority: argument based on thing's like what a cult leader has suggested.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Cherry-picking: Ignoring or choosing specific evidence to help the proponent's argument.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Circular reasoning: arguing for a conclusion on the basic of a set of premises, where the truth of those premises assumes the truth of the conclusion.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Complex question: Posing a question that contains a complex presupposition. While not stated, it is required for the question to make sense. Ie "have you stopped beating your wife?"`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Equivocation: think LOTR "no man can kill me", "I am no man".`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Fake precision: "70% of stats you read in books are just made up by the author"`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Fallacy of Composition`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Fallacy of Division`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`False Analogy: A is C, B is C, A is P. Therefore B is P.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`False Dilemma: given that there is limited options, when in fact, there are more.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Hasty Generalisation: A small sample has property X, therefore all have property X.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Just Because: A propenent argues because it is his proposition.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Lucid Fallacy: Argument based on circumstantial, specific parameters.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Lying with Stats`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Magical Thinking: Debate based on the supernatural.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Moralistic Fallcy. P ought to be the case, therefore P.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Moving the Goalposts: Raising or lowering the standard of proof required for an argument after an argument has been provided.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Multiple Comparisons Fallcy: Drawing significant statistical inferences from any positive or negative results gleaned from tests conduted on a multiplicity of groups or criteria.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Naturalistic Fallacy: P is natural, therefore P ought to be done.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Nirvana Fallacy: Something on the grounds that it does not resolve the problem completely.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Non Sequitur: When one statement is presented as following from another, while it logically does not exist.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Proving Nonexistence: Proof on that grounds that proving it's nonexistence cannot be proven.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Red Herring: Attempting to derail an argument by bringing in considerations that are irrelevant or out-of-context.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Reductio Ad Absurdum: Refuting an argument by drawing out allegedly absurd consequences from the argument.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Reuctio Ad Hitlerum: Dismissing the opponent's grounds on the basis that an evil figure believed in it.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Self-Sealing Argument: An argument presented in a way that is irrefutable.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Shoehorning: When a contributor derails an argument by discussing his own favoured topic.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Slippery Slope: Prediciting horrific consequences will follow seemingly innocuous action.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Special Pleading: Establishing a general rule for the debate but pleading for an exception for a particular circumstance.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Spiritual Fallacy: an argument based on "enlightenment"`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Straw Man Argument: Misrepresenting your opponent's argument, and taking this attack to refute your opponent's real position.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Sunk Cost: A reluctance to let go of an initial investment, so you continue investing.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Unfalsifiability: A substantive proposition expressed in such a way that it becomes, in principle, impossible to raise a counter-example to it.`}</MDXTag>
<MDXTag name="li" components={components} parentName="ul">{`Use-Mention Error: Confusing the discussion of the word itself with discussig the concept the word denotes.`}</MDXTag>
</MDXTag>
           </MDXTag>
  }
}
